'''''Detroit''''' is a 2017 American [[Period film|period]] [[crime film|crime drama]] film directed by [[Kathryn Bigelow]] and written by [[Mark Boal]]. Based on [[The Algiers Motel Incident]] during Detroit's 1967 [[1967 Detroit riot|12th Street Riot]], the film's release commemorated the 50th anniversary of the event.<ref name=DFP>{{Cite news |last=Hinds |first=Julie |origyear=June 21, 2016 |date=June 22, 2016 |title=Detroit 1967 riot movie will film here—at least partly |url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2016/06/21/movie-detroit-riots-1967-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-algiers-motel/85830068/ |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |access-date=April 12, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> The film stars [[John Boyega]], [[Will Poulter]], [[Algee Smith]], [[Jacob Latimore]], [[Jason Mitchell (actor) | Jason Mitchell]], [[Hannah Murray]], [[Kaitlyn Dever]], [[Jack Reynor]], Ben O'Toole, Nathan Davis Jr., [[Peyton Alex Smith]], [[Malcolm David Kelley]], [[Joseph David-Jones]], with [[John Krasinski]] and [[Anthony Mackie]].
''Detroit'' premiered at the [[Fox Theatre (Detroit)|Fox Theatre]], [[Detroit]], on July 26, 2017, and began a limited theatrical release on August 4, 2017.<ref name="release">{{cite web|last1=Lesnick|first1=Silas|title=Annapurna Pictures Dates Kathryn Bigelow’s Untitled Detroit Project|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/805519-annapurna-pictures|website=[[ComingSoon.net]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref> The film received positive reviews<!--I ask prospective editors to refrain from editing the directly preceding words before the issue is resolved on the talk page. I am beginning a new section there currently.--> from critics, with particular praise towards Bigelow's direction, Boal's screenplay and the performances of [[John Boyega]], [[Will Poulter]] and [[Algee Smith]]<ref name=reviews>{{cite news |title='Detroit': What other film critics are saying |url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2017/07/27/detroit-film-critics-say/104033994/ |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=July 27, 2017 |accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name=reviews2>{{cite web|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/dark-tower-condemned/|title=Dark Tower Condemned|first=Jeff|last=Giles|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|date=August 3, 2017|accessdate=August 17, 2017}}</ref> but was a [[Box office bomb|box office failure]], only grossing $24 million against its $34 million budget.
== Plot == On July 23, 1967, the [[Detroit Police Department]] staged a raid on an [[Blind pig|unlicensed club]] during a celebration for returning black veterans from the [[Vietnam War]]. While suspects are being arrested, a mob forms and starts throwing rocks at the officers before looting nearby stores and starting fires, beginning the [[12th Street Riot]]. With state authorities, elected representatives, and even emergency services unable to maintain any semblance of order, Governor [[George W. Romney]] authorizes the [[Michigan Army National Guard]] and President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] authorizes [[paratroopers#United States|Army paratroopers]] to enter Detroit in order to provide assistance. On the second day of rioting, two cops pursue a fleeing looter. One of them, Philip Krauss, kills the man with a shotgun against orders, but is allowed to remain on duty until his superiors can decide whether to file murder charges.
[[The Dramatics]], a professional black [[R&B]] group, arrive in Detroit hoping to score a recording contract. Seconds before their scheduled performance at a music hall, the police shut down the venue and order them to leave the city. En route, their bus is attacked by rioters and the group subsequently splits up, with lead singer Larry Reed and his friend Fred Temple renting a room at the local Algiers Motel for the night. They meet two white girls, Julie Ann and Karen, who introduce them to their friends Carl Cooper and Aubrey Pollard. Carl and another friend stage a prank using a [[Starting pistol|starter pistol]], upsetting Julie and Karen, who move to the room of Greene, a Vietnam War veteran, while Larry and Fred return to their own room.
Melvin Dismukes, a private [[security guard]], is assigned to protect a grocery store from looters and ingratiates himself with the Guardsmen. Carl decides to fire several blanks from his pistol in the direction of the troops to frighten them, but they mistake it for a [[sniper]] attack and pinpoint it coming from the Algiers due to the pistol's [[muzzle flash]]. The [[Michigan State Police]], National Guard, and Detroit Police arrive at the motel to investigate, led by Detroit police officer Krauss. Entering the building, they gun down Carl when he tries to escape, and Krauss plants a knife next to his body as he bleeds out and dies.
They round up everyone in the hotel and line them against the wall, demanding to know who the sniper was. Despite not finding any weapon during a search of the room, Krauss terrorizes and interrogates the occupants of the hotel. Dismukes arrives to try to help. Unwilling to get involved, most of the state police and National Guard leave without informing anyone of Krauss's abuse.
Krauss orders several suspects to be moved to different rooms and subjected to [[mock execution]]s in order to terrify the others into confessing. One police officer actually kills Aubrey, as he didn't understand the executions were supposed to be faked. Julie and Karen are taken to an upstairs room when they begin screaming, and Julie's clothes are torn off. Disgusted, a Guardsman returns, and manages to get them released from custody. Fearing arrest, Krauss permits the remaining suspects to leave, but only if they swear to keep silent. Greene and Larry agree, but Fred is killed when he refuses.
As the riots die down, Dismukes, while working his other job in a factory, is arrested and charged with murder after Julie identifies him as being present at the Algiers that night. Krauss and his fellow officers are questioned as well, and when everyone except Krauss confesses, they are also charged. Larry, whose singing career has stalled due to the trauma he experienced, is summoned as a witness to testify. The judge ultimately refuses to accept any of the confessions as evidence, and without a solid case, the all-white jury acquits Dismukes, Krauss, and their co-defendants of all charges. Dismukes confronts Krauss with the truth, but finds himself powerless to get any justice for the victims.
The film ends by explaining what became of the participants: Dismukes moved to the suburbs to escape death threats and resumed work as a security guard, Krauss and his men never returned to active duty, Julie rebuilt her life and started a family, and Larry became a choir singer and still lives in Detroit to the present day.

== Production == On January 28, 2016, it was announced that [[Kathryn Bigelow]] and [[Mark Boal]] would reteam to make a film about the [[1967 Detroit riot]]s, with Bigelow directing from a script by Boal.<ref name=Jan2016D>{{cite news|last1=Jr|first1=Mike Fleming|title=Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal Push Back Bowe Bergdahl For 1967 Detroit Race Riots Crime Drama Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-bowe-bergdahl-true-crime-drama-pic-1201692379/|accessdate=January 29, 2016|work=Deadline|date=January 28, 2016}}</ref> Both would also produce the film, along with [[Annapurna Pictures]]' [[Megan Ellison]] and Matthew Budman.<ref name="Jan2016D" /> ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' actress [[Hannah Murray]] was cast in a "key role" in the film, although her character was then being kept under wraps.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/kathryn-bigelow-hannah-murray/|title=Kathryn Bigelow Recruits ‘Game of Thrones’ Star Hannah Murray For Her Next Film}}</ref> The film was scheduled to shoot in the summer of 2016, in order to be released in 2017 for the 50th anniversary of the riots. On June 21, 2016, [[John Boyega]] joined the cast.<ref name="BoyegaCast">{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=John Boyega Joins Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Crime Drama (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-boyega-joins-kathryn-bigelows-905054|accessdate=June 22, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 21, 2016}}</ref> On August 3, 2016, [[Jack Reynor]], [[Will Poulter]], and Ben O'Toole were cast in lead roles.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Detroit Riots Film Casts Will Poulter, Ben O’Toole, Jack Reynor (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riots-movie-will-poulter-jack-reynor-ben-otoole-1201823845/|work=Variety|date=August 3, 2016}}</ref> On August 4, 2016, [[Anthony Mackie]] joined the cast,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr.|first1=Mike|title= Anthony Mackie Reunites With ‘Hurt Locker’s Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal In Detroit Riots Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2016/08/anthony-mackie-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-detroit-riots-the-hurt-locker-1201798650/|work=Deadline.com|date=August 4, 2016}}</ref> and on August 5, 2016, [[Jacob Latimore]] and Algee Smith also joined.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|last2=Ford|first2=Rebecca|title=Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Riots Drama Adds Two Rising Stars (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kathryn-bigelows-detroit-riots-drama-905111|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 5, 2016}}</ref> On August 8, 2016, [[Joseph David-Jones]] joined the cast,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riots-movie-joseph-david-jones-1201832533/|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Detroit Riots Film Casts ‘Legends of Tomorrow’s’ Joseph David-Jones|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=August 8, 2016|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> followed by [[Kaitlyn Dever]] on August 30, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Riot Drama Adds Kaitlyn Dever ===Filming=== It was reported at the end of July 2016 that the film had commenced [[principal photography]] in [[Boston]] during the previous week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Untitled Detroit Project, starring John Boyega, begins filming in Massachusetts|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2016/07/29/kathryn-bigelows-untitled-detroit-project-starring-john-boyega-begins-filming-massachusetts/|date=July 29, 2016|work=On Location Vacations|accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Aurise|first1=Elana|title=Feature film shoots scenes on Ashmont Street|url=http://www.dotnews.com/2016/feature-film-shoots-scenes-ashmont-street|date=July 28, 2016|work=Dorchester Reporter|accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref> Scenes were filmed inside [[Dedham District Court]],<ref name=movie>{{cite news | url = http://patch.com/massachusetts/dedham/kathryn-bigelow-movie-be-filmed-dedham | title = Kathryn Bigelow Movie to be Filmed in Dedham | publisher = Dedham Patch | first = Daniel | last = Libon | date = August 20, 2016 | accessdate = August 20, 2016 }}</ref> in [[Dorchester, Massachusetts]] and in [[Brockton, Massachusetts]].<ref name=chester>{{cite news | title = Filming continues in Detroit-chester | url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/names/2016/08/19/filming-continues-detroit-chester/GY5DtKDwG1sNPrtGokNVjK/story.html | first = Emily | last = Sweeney | publisher = The Boston Globe | date = August 19, 2016 | accessdate = August 21, 2016}}</ref> In addition, the movie filmed in Detroit during October 2016. The elimination of Michigan's film incentives in 2015 affected the filming locations.<ref name=DFP/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2016/10/04/detroit-riot-movie-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-motor-city-filming/91533922/|title=Detroit riot movie will film in Motor City this week|work=Detroit Free Press|access-date=April 13, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Post-production=== In May 2017, [[James Newton Howard]] was hired as the film's composer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2017/05/08/james-newton-howard-to-score-kathryn-bigelows-detroit/|title=James Newton Howard to Score Kathryn Bigelow’s ‘Detroit’|date=May 8, 2017|accessdate=May 8, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017, Detroit rapper [[Tee Grizzley]] released a song called "Teetroit" for the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/07/28/tee-grizzley-teetroit|title=Tee Grizzley’s Urgent New Song "Teetroit" Might Radicalize You|date=July 28, 2017|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref> [[The Roots]] and [[Bilal (American singer)|Bilal]] released a song named "It Ain't Fair" for the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2017/07/27/the_roots_and_bilal_reteam_for_a_stirring_new_song_from_the_movie_detroit.html|title=Listen to the Roots and Bilal’s Stirring New Song From the Detroit Soundtrack, “It Ain’t Fair”|first=Meeran|last=Karim|date=July 27, 2017|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref>
==Release== ''Detroit'' began a limited release in 10 markets on July 28, 2017, opening in New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas, Washington D.C., Detroit, San Francisco, Houston, Atlanta, and Baltimore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/emoji-movie-atomic-blonde-dunkirk-detroit-weekend-box-office-1202136629/|title=‘Emoji Movie’ & ‘Atomic Blonde’ Vie To Take ‘Dunkirk’ Brigade Out At Box Office|publisher=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 26, 2017|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref> [[Annapurna Pictures]] then released the film nationally, its first as a distributor, on August 4, 2017.<ref name="release"/> Annapurna handled the film's North American distribution, while [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] and [[Entertainment One]] handled distribution for its international release.<ref name=Variety>{{cite web|last=McNary|first=Dave|title=Bruce Willis’ ‘Death Wish’ Remake Lands November Launch With Annapurna|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/bruce-willis-death-wish-remake-annapurna-1202459109/|accessdate=June 8, 2017|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> On November 3, 2017, it was announced the film would get a ten city, 20 screen re-release on December 1, 2017 in an effort to push its award campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/detroit-movie-back-in-theaters-kathryn-bigelow-new-trailer-1202200936/|title=Annapurna Puts Kathryn Bigelow-Directed ‘Detroit’ Back In Theaters For Limited Run: Watch New Trailer|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 3, 2017|accessdate=November 8, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Detroit'' grossed $16.8 million in the United States and Canada and $7.3 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $24.1 million, against a production budget of $34 million.<ref name=NUM/>
In North America, ''Detroit'' grossed $350,190 in its limited opening from 20 theaters (an average of $17,510), finishing 16th at the box office.<ref name=limited>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/atomic-blonde-dunkirk-emoji-movie-weekend-box-office-openings-1202138047/|title=‘Dunkirk’ Marches Ahead Of ‘Emoji Movie’ For Top Spot With $28M+|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}</ref> The film then had its wide expansion alongside ''[[Kidnap (2017 film)|Kidnap]]'' and ''[[The Dark Tower (2017 film)|The Dark Tower]]'', and was initially projected to gross $10–15 million from 3,007 theaters over the weekend.<ref name=preview>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-fi-ct-movie-projector-dark-tower-20170802-htmlstory.html|title=Sony's long-awaited 'Dark Tower' may unseat 'Dunkirk' with $25-million box-office premiere|website=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=August 2, 2017}}</ref> The film made $525,000 from Thursday previews, which was more than the $515,482 it made in its entire week of limited release. It then made $2.6 million on its first day, lowering weekend projections to $7.5 million.<ref name=opening>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/the-dark-tower-detroit-kidnap-dunkirk-weekend-box-office-opening-1202142448/|title=‘The Dark Tower’ Opens To $18M+ In Diverse Marketplace: Was The Decade-Plus Battle To The Screen Worth It?|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 5, 2017}}</ref> It went on to open to $7.1 million, finishing 8th at the box office; 40% of its opening weekend audience were African American. [[Deadline Hollywood]] said that the film could have done better had it been released in the fall during festivals and awards season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/the-dark-tower-detroit-kidnap-weak-summer-box-office-weekend-1202143411/|title=‘The Dark Tower’ Is Tall Enough For No. 1 With $19.5M During Sluggish Summer Weekend|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 7, 2017}}</ref> In its second weekend the film grossed $2.9 million, dropping 59.5% (above average for an adult drama) and finishing in 13th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/annabelle-creation-dark-tower-dunkirk-1202147007/|title='Annabelle: Creation' Comes Alive On Thursday With $4M|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=August 11, 2017}}</ref> In its third week of wide release the film was pulled from 1,579 theaters and grossed $850,000 (a drop of 70.9%).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/hitmans-bodyguard-logan-lucky-annabelle-creation-august-box-office-opening-1202152509/|title='Hitman’s Bodyguard’ Flexes Muscle With $21M+ Opening During Sleepy Summer Weekend|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017}}</ref>
===Critical response=== ''Detroit'' received praise for its direction, screenplay, and acting, especially Boyega, Poulter, and Smith's performances.<ref name=reviews/><ref name=reviews2/> On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 83% based on 260 reviews, and an [[average rating]] of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''Detroit'' delivers a gut-wrenching – and essential – dramatisation of a tragic chapter from America's past that draws distressing parallels to the present."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/detroit_2017 |title=Detroit (2017) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media|Fandango]] |accessdate=August 28, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film has a weighted average score of 77 out of 100, based on 49 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/detroit |title=Detroit Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=July 6, 2018}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave it an 86% overall positive score and a 63% "definite recommend".<ref name=opening/>
[[Richard Roeper]] of ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film 4 out of 4 stars and called it one of 2017's best, saying: "Journalist-screenwriter Mark Boal (Bigelow's collaborator on ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' and ''[[Zero Dark Thirty]]'') does a magnificent job of juggling the multiple storylines and creating fully authentic characters—some flawed, some basically decent, some evil."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/roeper-tight-focus-intensifies-the-drama-of-riot-recap-detroit/ |title=Tight focus intensifies the drama of riot recap 'Detroit'|website=[[Chicago Sun Times]] |date=July 25, 2016|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', [[Peter Travers]] praised the cast and script, giving the film 3.5/4 stars and saying, "... ''Detroit'' is far more than a liberal howl against the escalating toxicity of racism in America. Bigelow, with the same immersive intensity that [[Christopher Nolan]] brings to ''[[Dunkirk (2017 film)|Dunkirk]]'', smacks us down in the middle of a brutal historical event so we can see it – and feel it – for ourselves."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/peter-travers-detroit-will-leave-you-moved-scarred-w493733|title='Detroit' Review: Kathryn Bigelow's Recreation of Riots, Racism Is Cry of Rage |last=Travers |first=Peter |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
Conversely, Alexander Nazaryan of ''[[Newsweek]]'' said, "[Bigelow's] characters never come alive, moving through the film less as people than entries in a sociology textbook ... If Bigelow could get inside the minds of soldiers suffocated by post-traumatic stress disorder, as she did so capably in ''The Hurt Locker'', she can get into the mind of anyone. In ''Zero Dark Thirty'', she made even CIA interrogators likeable. The characters in ''Detroit'', though, black and white, are as flat as the plains of the Upper Midwest."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2017/07/28/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-race-riots-movie-review-642376.html |title=Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' Is A Well-intentioned Misfire|website=[[Newsweek]] |date=July 26, 2016|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref>
Several critics noted the film's questionable take on a predominantly African American-based story. [[A. O. Scott]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, "It is curious that a movie set against a backdrop of black resistance and rebellion—however inchoate and self-destructive its expression may have been—should become a tale of black helplessness and passivity. The white men, the decent ones as much as the brutes, have the answers, the power, the agency."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Scott|first1=A.O. |title=In Detroit, Black Lives Caught in the Pre-History of the Alt-Right |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/movies/detroit-review.html|work=The New York Times }}</ref> K. Austin Collins of ''[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]]'' wrote, "This movie isn't really about black people as people, nor history as a lived experience, but is instead invested in a dutiful, 'just the facts, ma'am' reenactment that pretends those other things are already a given. Boal, and Bigelow beside him, refuse to speculate about — or imagine — the rest."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Collins |first1=K. Austin |date=July 28, 2017 |title='Detroit' Gives Us the Who, What, and Where, but Not the Why |url=https://theringer.com/detroit-film-review-kathryn-bigelow-john-boyega-4b4fbe64d509 |publisher=[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]] |access-date=August 2, 2017}}</ref>
''[[The New Yorker]]''{{'}}s Richard Brody called the film "a moral failure", saying: "[Bigelow's] intentions come through clearly: to depict an incident—and a climate—of racism, to show that the cruelty of these deeds was multiplied by their ultimate impunity, and to suggest that, in the intervening half-century since the events depicted in the film took place, little has changed. Movies aren’t made with intentions, though; they’re made with people and with equipment, and what Bigelow has her actors do for the benefit of the camera is repellent to imagine."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brody |first1=Richard |date=August 27, 2017 |title=The Immoral Artistry of Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/the-immoral-artistry-of-kathryn-bigelows-detroit |publisher=[[The New Yorker (website)|The New Yorker]] |access-date=August 27, 2017}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Date of ceremony ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col"| {{Abbr|Ref.|References}} |- | rowspan="4"| [[Black Reel Awards]] | rowspan="4"| February 22, 2018 | Outstanding Film | ''Detroit'' | {{nom}} | rowspan="4"| <ref>[http://blackreelawards.com/get-out-dominate-the-black-reel-awards/ Get Out Dominates the Black Reel Awards] Black Reel Awards. 13 December 2017.</ref><ref>[http://blackreelawards.com/get-out-sinks-the-competition-at-the-black-reel-awards/ Get Out “Sinks” the Competition at The Black Reel Awards] Black Reel Awards. 23 February 2018.</ref> |- | Outstanding Actor, Motion Picture | [[Algee Smith]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Ensemble | [[Victoria Thomas]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Score | [[James Newton Howard]] | {{nom}} |- |rowspan="5"| [[49th NAACP Image Awards|NAACP Image Awards]] |rowspan="5"| January 15, 2018 | [[49th NAACP Image Awards#Motion Picture|Outstanding Motion Picture]] | ''Detroit'' | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture | Algee Smith | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Writing in a Motion Picture | [[Mark Boal]] | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Independent Motion Picture | Detroit | {{won}} | |- |}
==Historical accuracy== According to Melvin Dismukes, who is depicted prominently in the film, ''Detroit'' "is 99.5% accurate as to what went down at the Algiers and in the city at the time."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/detroit-melvin-dismukes-interview-1202511170/|title=‘Detroit’ Subject Melvin Dismukes on What Kathryn Bigelow Film Gets Right|first=Brent|last=Lang|date=August 1, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> However, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that "Bigelow does say there are moments of fiction, and Boal notes instances of 'pure screenwriting.' Some facts are contested within accounts; others were changed for the screen" and then raised the question "Does a disclaimer at the end sufficiently cover fictional manipulations in an ostensibly true story?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-ca-mn-detroit-bigelow-20170727-story.html|title=Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' takes on a tragedy then — and now - Los Angeles Times|first=Steven|last=Zeitchik|website=latimes.com}}</ref> [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] went so far as to state that Bigelow and Boal "changed names [of characters] so as to enjoy other creative liberties in the storytelling."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/does-detroit-risk-a-lawsuit-real-life-cops-1026426|title=Does 'Detroit' Risk a Lawsuit From Real-Life Cops?|publisher=}}</ref> One such subject whose name was dropped in favor of a fictional one is lawyer Norman Lippitt (played in the film by actor [[John Krasinski]] under the name Auerbach).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20170722/news/634586/lawyer-who-earned-fame-defending-detroit-police-in-algiers-motel-case|title=Lawyer who earned fame defending Detroit police in Algiers Motel case recalls legacy|website=Crain's Detroit Business}}</ref>
In response to the historical criticism, Boal said, "I employed poetic license, under a self-imposed rule to never stray from what I understood to be the underlying truth of a scene or an event. This script is built on a sturdy base of journalism and history, but it is not the same as journalism or history, nor does it aspire to be. As a screenwriter, I take the responsibility of being the creator of a tale, of transforming these raw materials into a drama."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyvshollywood.com/reelfaces/detroit/|title=Detroit Movie vs. the True Story of the Algiers Motel Killings|publisher=}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Diablo Cody | image = Diablo Cody at TIFF 2009 cropped 2.jpg | caption = Cody at the [[2009 Toronto International Film Festival]] | birth_name = Brooke Busey | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1978|06|14}} | birth_place = [[Lemont, Illinois]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[University of Iowa]] | occupation = Writer, director, producer | residence = [[Los Angeles, California]] | years_active = 2005–present | spouse = {{marriage|Jon Hunt|2004|2007|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Dan Maurio|2009}} | children = 3 }} '''Brooke Busey-Maurio''' (born June 14, 1978), better known by the [[pen name]] '''Diablo Cody''',{{cite news|url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23360051/|title= What Makes Diablo Cody Unique Now Gets Pans|publisher= Associated Press via [[MSNBC]]|date= 2008-02-29|accessdate= 2008-03-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701091701/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/23360051|archivedate=July 1, 2010|deadurl=no}} is an American writer, director, and producer. She first became known for her candid memoir, ''[[Candy Girl: A Year in the Life of an Unlikely Stripper]]'' (2005), and the [[blog]] that preceded it. Later, Cody achieved critical acclaim for her debut feature film script, ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' (2007), winning awards such as the [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay]], the [[BAFTA Award for Best Original Screenplay]], the [[Independent Spirit Award for Best First Screenplay]], and the [[Writers Guild of America Award for Best Original Screenplay]]. She is also known for creating, writing, and producing [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s television series ''[[United States of Tara]]'' (2009–2011) and for writing and producing the films ''[[Jennifer's Body]]'' (2009) and ''[[Young Adult (film)|Young Adult]]'' (2011). For the latter, she received a second nomination for the Writers Guild of America Award for Best Original Screenplay.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/01/wga-awards-nominations-announced/ |title=WGA Awards Nominations Announced |publisher=Deadline.com |date= 2012-01-05|accessdate=2013-10-20}} Her [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]], ''[[Paradise (2013 film)|Paradise]]'', was released on October 18, 2013.{{cite news|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |title=Diablo Cody Celebrates 'Paradise,' Her Directorial Debut, With Hollywood Premiere |date=7 August 2013 |first=Jennifer |last=Calfas |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/julianne-hough-nick-offerman-celebrate-600880 |accessdate=2015-02-11}}{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Diablo Cody Re-Launches Her 'Red Band Trailer'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/10/diablo-cody-re-launches-her-red-band-trailer-web-talk-show-on-l-studio/|work=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=31 March 2012|date=5 October 2011}}{{cite news|author=Kira Cochrane |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/jan/08/2013-preview-cultural-women |title=2013 preview: the cultural year ahead for women | Life and style |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2013-01-08|accessdate=2013-10-20 |location=London}} ==Early life and career== Cody and her older brother Marc were born and raised in [[Lemont, Illinois]], a suburb of Chicago. She is the daughter of Pam and Greg Busey.{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-12-09/news/0712070510_1_mason-novick-hollywood-film-festival-diablo-cody |title=From Lemont to Hollywood, with a pole dance in between |date=9 December 2007 |last=Schaults |first=Janine |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=2015-02-11}} Her mother is of Italian descent and her father is of British ancestry.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G23CRWNF3IU; stated at 19:55 Cody was raised Catholic{{cite web|url=http://www.inkedmag.com/article/diablo-cody-says-no/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100316052258/http://www.inkedmag.com/article/diablo-cody-says-no/|archivedate=March 16, 2010 |title=Diablo Cody Says No|publisher=(interview), ''[[Inked (magazine)|Inked]]''| date= September 2009|deadurl=no}} and attended [[Benet Academy]], a Roman Catholic school in [[Lisle, Illinois]]. She took the pen name Diablo Cody (''diablo'' is Spanish for "devil") after repeatedly listening to the song "El Diablo" by [[Arcadia (band)|Arcadia]]{{cite news| url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20157948,00.html| title = Diablo Cody: From Ex-Stripper to A-Lister| accessdate = 2008-04-16| last = Valby|first=Karen| date = November 5, 2007| work = [[Entertainment Weekly]]}} while passing through [[Cody, Wyoming]]. She graduated from the [[University of Iowa]] with a [[media studies]] degree.{{cite news|last= Desson|first= Thomson|title= Hollywood takes a shine to 'Juno' writer's body of work|publisher= ''[[The Washington Post]]'' via Boston.com|date= 2007-12-15|url= http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2007/12/15/hollywood_takes_a_shine_to_juno_writers_body_of_work/|page = [http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2007/12/15/hollywood_takes_a_shine_to_juno_writers_body_of_work/?page=2 2]|accessdate= 2008-01-30| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100207020629/http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2007/12/15/hollywood_takes_a_shine_to_juno_writers_body_of_work/?page=2| archivedate=February 7, 2010|deadurl=no}} While at the [[University of Iowa]], she worked in the acquisitions department in the main university library.{{cite web|url=http://blog.lib.uiowa.edu/news/2008/02/|title=Former Student Assistant Wins Oscar|publisher=[[University of Iowa]] Libraries|date=February 26, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716155044/http://blog.lib.uiowa.edu/news/2008/02/ |archivedate=July 16, 2011|deadurl=no}} Her first jobs were doing secretarial work at a Chicago law firm and later [[proofreading]] [[copy (written)|copy]] for advertisements that played on [[Minneapolis-St. Paul|Twin Cities]] radio stations. Cody began a [[parody]] [[weblog|blog]] called ''Red Secretary'', detailing the (fictional) exploits of a secretary living in [[Belarus]].{{cite news|last= Abramowitz|first= Rachel|title= Diablo Cody: From stripper to screenwriter|work= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date= 2007-12-06|archiveurl= http://world-news-live.blogspot.com/2007/12/diablo-cody-from-stripper-to.html| archivedate=2008-02-25|url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-cody6dec06,0,5969724.story|accessdate= 2008-01-30}} The events were thinly-veiled allegories for events that happened in Cody's real life, but told from the perspective of a disgruntled, English-[[idiom]]-challenged [[Eastern Bloc]] girl. Her first ''bona fide'' blog appeared under the nickname ''Darling Girl'' after she had moved from Chicago to [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. ==Stripping and journalism== On a whim, Cody signed up for amateur night at a Minneapolis strip club called the Skyway Lounge. Having enjoyed the experience, she eventually quit her day job to become a full-time stripper.{{cite news|last= Scott|first= Megan|title= Unlikely pole dancer tells strippers' story|publisher= ''Orange County Register''|date= 2006-03-10|url= http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/features/lifestyle/article_1032959.php|accessdate= 2008-01-30|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080116224306/http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/features/lifestyle/article_1032959.php|archivedate= 2008-01-16|df= }} Cody also spent time working peep shows at Sex World, a Minneapolis adult novelty and DVD store.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} While still stripping, Cody began writing for ''[[City Pages]]'', an alternative [[Twin Cities]] weekly newspaper. She left ''City Pages'' just before it changed editorial hands, and has since written for the now-defunct ''[[Jane magazine|Jane]]'' magazine. In December 2007,{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20166555,00.html |title=Diablo Cody: As the Crowe Flies? |publisher=EW.com |date=2007-12-17 |accessdate=2013-12-01}} Cody began writing a column for the magazine ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. At the age of 27, Cody wrote her memoir ''[[Candy Girl: A Year in the Life of an Unlikely Stripper]]''. The memoir began after [[Mason Novick]], who would soon become Cody's manager, showed interest in her sharp and sarcastic voice. Based on the popularity of her blog, ''The Pussy Ranch'', he was able to secure her a publishing contract with [[Gotham Books]]. ==Screenwriting== [[File:Diablo Cody2.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Cody, January 2008]] After completion of her book, Cody was encouraged by [[Mason Novick]] to write her first screenplay.{{cite news|title= Ex-stripper in movie spotlight|publisher= CNN|date= 2008-01-23|url= http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/01/09/film.diablo.cody.ap/index.html|accessdate= 2008-01-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080118072752/http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/01/09/film.diablo.cody.ap/index.html |archivedate = January 18, 2008}} Within months she wrote ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'', a coming-of-age story about a teenager's unplanned pregnancy. The [[Jason Reitman]]-directed comedy stars [[Ellen Page]] and [[Michael Cera]].{{cite journal|title=First Look| journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]| page=7 |date=February 13, 2009 |issue=1034}} In July 2007, [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] announced that it would be producing a pilot of Cody's [[DreamWorks Television|DreamWorks]] television series, ''[[United States of Tara]]''. Based on an idea by [[Steven Spielberg]], ''Tara'' is a comedy about a mother with [[dissociative identity disorder]], starring [[Toni Collette]].{{cite news|title= Diablo Cody, lap dancer turned ace screenwriter|publisher= Times Online|date= 2008-01-20|url= http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article3199604.ece|accessdate= 2008-04-15 | location=London | first=Jeff | last=Dawson}} The series began filming in Spring 2008, and premiered on January 18, 2009. In October 2007, Cody sold a script titled ''Girly Style'' to [[Universal Studios]], and a horror script called ''[[Jennifer's Body]]'' to [[Fox Atomic]].{{cite news|last= Covert|first= Colin|title= Interview: Diablo Cody: Dancing as fast as she can|publisher= ''Minneapolis Star Tribune''|date= 2007-12-07|url= http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/movies/12219916.html|accessdate= 2008-01-30|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080209163008/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/movies/12219916.html|archivedate= 2008-02-09|df= }} Released on September 18, 2009, ''Jennifer's Body'' starred [[Megan Fox]] as the title character and [[Amanda Seyfried]] as the supporting character.{{cite news|last=Covert |first=Colin |title=In Defense Of 'Jennifer’s Body' |date=2007-12-07 |url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/3329313/defense-jennifers-body/ |website=[[Bloody Disgusting]] |accessdate=2008-01-30}} She revised writer-director [[Steven Antin]]'s script for his musical film ''[[Burlesque (2010 American film)|Burlesque]]''.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117974104|date=October 15, 2007|title=Screen Gems enlists Antin for 'Burlesque'|first=Michael |last=Fleming|accessdate=November 18, 2011|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118000000/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117974104|archivedate=November 18, 2011|deadurl=no}} Cody is a friend of screenwriters [[Dana Fox]] (''[[What Happens in Vegas]]'', ''[[Couples Retreat]]'') and [[Lorene Scafaria]] (''[[Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist]]'') and they often write their screenplays together in order to get advice from one another.{{cite web | url= http://virtual.torontosun.com/doc/toronto-sun-special-sections/0907/2008090701/24.html#24| title= The Fempire strikes back|accessdate= 2015-08-28| date=September 7, 2008 | publisher= [[Toronto Sun]]|last= Slotek|first= Jim}} Cody made a small cameo appearance as herself in the U.S. broadcast television series ''[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]'' (2008). She appeared in the same episode that marked the return of [[Tori Spelling]] as [[Donna Martin]], in which Cody needed Spelling's character to make a dress for a red carpet event. In 2009, Cody signed on to script and produce a film adaptation of the ''[[Sweet Valley High]]'' [[young adult fiction|young adult]] book series.{{cite news | first=Dave |last=McNary | title=Diablo Cody takes on 'Sweet Valley'| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118008999 | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=23 September 2009 | accessdate=2011-11-18|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111118000000/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118008999| archivedate=November 18, 2011|deadurl=no}} In 2011, she was brought in to revise first-time feature director Fede Alvarez's script for the remake of [[Sam Raimi]]'s 1980s horror film ''[[The Evil Dead]]''.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2011/07/evil-dead-remake-diablo-cody-polishing-script-for-first-time-director.html|title='Evil Dead' remake: Diablo Cody polishing script for first-time director|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 13, 2011 | first=Gina|last= McIntyre}} Since October, 2011, Cody has hosted an online celebrity interview program called "Red Band Trailer," on the broadband channel, L-studio.{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Diablo Cody Re-Launches Her 'Red Band Trailer' Web Talk Show On L Studio|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/10/diablo-cody-re-launches-her-red-band-trailer-web-talk-show-on-l-studio/|work=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=31 March 2012|date=5 October 2011}} She originally launched the series privately on YouTube in summer 2010, and the Lexus channel picked it up the following year. On the ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]'' podcast, on February 24, 2012, she said her next project would be directing her first film, which is about a young woman who abandons religion after surviving a plane crash. In February 2013, she said that the film is called ''[[Paradise (2013 film)|Paradise]]'' (firstly known as ''Lamb of God''). [[Julianne Hough]], [[Holly Hunter]], [[Octavia Spencer]], and [[Russell Brand]] are in the cast. [[Mandate Pictures]] produced it.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/diablo-cody-paradise-athena-film-festival-interview/ |title=Diablo Cody Talks PARADISE, SWEET VALLEY HIGH, and the Athena Film Festival |publisher=Collider |date= 2013-02-05|accessdate=2013-10-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=79150 |title=Diablo Cody Making Directing Debut with Lamb of God |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=2011-06-29 |accessdate=2013-10-20}} Cody is the [[spokesperson]] of [[Barnard College]]'s Athena Film Festival.{{cite web|url=http://athenafilmfestival.com/2013/01/29/diablo-cody-opens-up-about-her-passion-project/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426172911/http://www.etonline.com/movies/129782_Diablo_Cody_Sweet_Valley_High_Interview_Athena_Film_Festival/ |title=Diablo Cody Opens Up About Her Passion Project |archivedate=2013-04-26 |publisher=Athena Film Festival |date= 2013-01-28|accessdate=2013-10-20}} ==Projects== In May 2013, it was announced that Cody will host her own talk show, ''Me Time with Diablo Cody'', at [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]]. The program will tailor "around Diablo’s unique perspective on all things pop culture and told in her very own tongue-in-cheek way," and "reveal a side of Hollywood and celebs that the public very rarely gets to see." [[Steve Agee]] will be presenting and writing with her as well. Cody is also a producer, alongside Mark Cronin and Courtland Cox. The pilot of the talk show is in works.{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/06/diablo-cody-gets-sidekick-for-her-tbs-talk-show-pilot/ |title=Diablo Cody Gets Sidekick For Her TBS Talk Show Pilot |publisher=Deadline.com |date= 2013-06-04|accessdate=2013-10-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/tbs-developing-diablo-cody-talk-show |title=TBS is Developing a Talk Show With Diablo Cody | Filmmakers, Film Industry, Film Festivals, Awards & Movie Reviews |publisher=Indiewire |date=2012-10-26 |accessdate=2013-10-20}} She is currently developing a teen-drama TV series with [[Josh Schwartz]] for [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] called ''Prodigy''. According to ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', it is about "a 16-year-old genius who through home schooling has been isolated from her peers. Hoping to experience a "normal" teen social life before she enters the adult world of academia, she enrolls in her local high school. Her experiment goes off the rails when she finds herself adopted by a wild crowd, getting caught up in a whirlwind of romance and crime."{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/diablo-cody-paradise-prodigy-interview/ |title=Diablo Cody Talks PARADISE, Being "Scared Shitless," PRODIGY, SWEET VALLEY HIGH, and More |website=Collider |date= 2013-10-18|accessdate=2013-10-20}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/diablo-cody-teams-fake-empire-643511 |title=Diablo Cody Teams With Fake Empire for Fox Teen Drama 'Prodigy' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2013-10-04 |accessdate=2013-10-20 |first=Lesley |last=Goldberg}} Cody is also linked to [[Warner Bros. Television]]'s romantic comedy ''Alex+Amy''.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/diablo-cody-developing-romantic-comedy-abc-386188 |title=Diablo Cody Developing Romantic Comedy at ABC |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2011-11-17 |accessdate=2013-10-20 |first=Lesley |last=Goldberg}} ==Personal life== In her book, she wrote fondly of her boyfriend "Jonny" (musician Jon Hunt of Minneapolis psych-folk band, Lovely Dark). They were married from 2004 until 2007,{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} during which time she was known in personal life as Brook Busey-Hunt. On April 6, 2010, Cody announced that she was expecting her first child with her husband Dan Maurio, who worked on ''[[Chelsea Lately]]'', on which Cody also appeared frequently as a "roundtable" guest. The couple married in the summer of 2009.{{cite news | title= Diablo Cody Expecting a Baby!|publisher= Celebrity Moms|date= 2010-04-06|url=http://celebrity-moms.blogspot.com/2010/04/diablo-cody-expecting-baby.html}} Their son was born in 2010.{{cite news | title= @diablocody|publisher= Twitter|date= 2010-07-27|url=https://twitter.com/diablocody/status/19698425357}} Cody had her second child in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/womenandhollywood/quote-of-the-day-i-wanted-to-show-people-that-pregnancy-is-not-a-disability-and-a-pregnant-lady-can-be-in-a-position-of-power-and-crazy-shit-wont-happen-diablo-cody |title=Pregnant Lady Can Be in a Position of Power and Crazy Shit Won't Happen - Diablo Cody |author=Silverstein, Melissa |publisher=IndieWire |date=October 31, 2013 |accessdate=September 29, 2013 }} {{as of|2018||}}, Cody and Maurio have three children.{{cite web|last1=Stewart|first1=Sara|title=Diablo Cody's Kids Have No Idea She's Famous|url=https://nypost.com/2018/05/03/diablo-codys-kids-have-no-idea-shes-famous/|accessdate=4 May 2018|date=2018-05-04}} As of 2008, Cody resides in Los Angeles. ==Nominations and awards== ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' was runner-up for the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] People's Choice Award, won second prize at the Rome Film Festival, and earned four [[Academy Award]] nominations, including one for [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]. Cody herself won an Academy Award for [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] for her debut script, which also picked up a [[Golden Globes|Golden Globe]] nomination and an [[Independent Spirit Award for Best First Screenplay]]. She also won screenplay honors from [[BAFTA]], the [[Writers Guild of America Awards|Writers Guild of America]], the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]], the [[National Board of Review]], the [[Satellite Awards]], and the 2008 [[Cinema for Peace|Cinema for Peace Award for Most Valuable Work of Director, Producer & Screenwriter]] (which she shared with Jason Reitman, [[John Malkovich]], Mason Novick, Russel Smith and [[Lianne Halfon]]).{{cite news|author=Michael Jones |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117980855/?refcatid=38&printerfriendly=true |title=Berlin’s Peace Awards bring in celebs |publisher=Variety |date=2008-02-12 |accessdate=2013-10-20}} For ''[[Young Adult (film)|Young Adult]]'', Cody was nominated by awards associations such as the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]] and the [[Writers Guild of America Awards|Writers Guild of America]]. With Reitman, the director, and the actors [[Charlize Theron]] and [[Patton Oswalt]], she shared the Chairman's Vanguard Award at the [[Palm Springs International Film Festival]]. In 2012, the Fempire, the collaboration of writers Cody, [[Dana Fox]], [[Liz Meriwether]], and [[Lorene Scafaria]] received the Creativity and Sisterhood Award from the Athena Film Festival for their support for one another in the competitive film industry.{{cite web|url=http://athenafilmfestival.com/awards/award-winners/2012-athena-award-winners/ |website=Athena Film Festival |title=2012 Athena Award Winners |accessdate=2015-02-13}} ==Works== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Dulcie Sybil Holland <small>AM</small> |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1913|01|05|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2000|05|21|1913|01|05|df=y}} |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = Australian |other_names = |known_for = |education = |employer = |occupation = Composer, teacher, performer |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relatives = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Dulcie Sybil Holland'''<ref>Also known by her married name as Dulcie Bellhouse or Mrs Dulcie Sybil Bellhouse.</ref> [[Order of Australia|AM]] (5 January 1913 – 21 May 2000) was an Australian [[composer]] and music educator. Best known for her contributions to music education through her energetic involvement with the [[Australian Music Examinations Board]], Holland has in recent decades gained greater recognition as a composer. She is now regarded by some critics as one of the more significant Australian composers of her generation.
==Education== Dulcie Holland was born in [[Sydney]] in 1913. She began taking piano lessons at the age of six, and attended Shirley School for Girls, known for its academic excellence. In 1929 she entered the New South Wales Conservatorium of Music (now the [[Sydney Conservatorium of Music|Sydney Conservatorium]]) to continue her studies. At the Conservatorium she studied [[piano]] with [[Grace Middenway]] and [[Frank Hutchens]], [[cello]] with [[Gladstone Bell]], and composition with [[Roy Agnew]] and [[Alfred Hill (composer)|Alfred Hill]], eventually completing both the Diploma course (DSCM) and the [[Licentiate (degree)|Licentiate]] of the [[Royal Schools of Music]] (LRSM) in 1933.
In 1936, Holland travelled to [[London]] to study composition at the [[Royal College of Music]] with [[John Ireland (composer)|John Ireland]]. At the end of her first year, she won the Blumenthal Scholarship for composition, which entitled her to another three years of study at the College. The following year she won the Cobbett Prize for [[chamber music]], but with the outbreak of [[World War II]] in 1939, decided to return to Australia.
Several years after the war, in 1951, she returned to the United Kingdom for a year to study [[serialism]] with [[Mátyás Seiber]].
==Career== After returning to Australia from the Royal College in 1939, Holland embarked on a career as a recitalist and freelance composer. In 1940 she married the Australian [[Conducting|conductor]] [[Alan Bellhouse]], with whom she would have two children. During the 1940s, in addition to her childrearing and composing, she wrote a number of children's books, under her married name of Dulcie Bellhouse. She also began to write music for the North Shore Symphony Orchestra (founded and conducted by her husband), an association that would continue for 25 years.
In the 1950s, Holland was commissioned to write [[Film score|musical score]]s for the [[Minister for Home Affairs (Australia)|Department of the Interior]], which was then producing a number of documentary films about Australian life for the new wave of migrants entering the country. She eventually wrote the scores for forty of these films.
In 1967, Holland joined the [[Australian Music Examinations Board]] (AMEB) as an examiner.<ref>Music Australia website.</ref> During her long association with the Board, her prolific output of musical studies and pieces for students at all levels of development, along with her authorship of numerous music theory books, were eventually to make her a familiar name in thousands of Australian households. Sales of her didactic writings made her Australia's most celebrated music author.
After her retirement from AMEB in 1983, Holland continued to compose, but chose to focus more on the writing of music text books, on the ground that she believed "making new converts to music" to be more important than adding to the volume of existing music.<ref>Fuller and LeFanu, p. 153.</ref>
In 1977, she was made a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] (AM). In 1993, along with [[Miriam Hyde]], she was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Letters (D.Litt.) by [[Macquarie University]].
==Music== Throughout the course of her seventy-year career, Holland produced a considerable body of serious (as opposed to educational) music. Her work includes orchestral pieces (including a symphony), vocal and choral works, a large output of chamber music featuring different combinations of instruments, and many pieces for piano and other solo performance. She wrote in both the contemporary and neo-classical genres.
===Style=== Dulcie Holland has been described as "less conservative and more appealing than many of her contemporaries".<ref name=resonate/> Her music is generally "melodic, optimistic and sunny", and even her darker moods are "reflective and lyrical".<ref name=sitmar43>Sitsky and Martin, p. 43.</ref> She employs "non-traditional key relationships and swiftly changing tonal centres",<ref name=resonate>''Resonate''.</ref> and is "fond of the pentatonic scale with its built-in ambiguities, and the possibilities thus given to modulate to unexpected keys".<ref name=sitmar43/> Overall however, her music is said to convey a "sense of balance, of confidence, of individuality [and] of formal structure".<ref name=resonate/>
===Major works=== In addition to the symphony and string quartet, Holland's ''Piano Sonata'' has been called "undoubtedly a landmark work in the Australian oeuvre",<ref>Sitsky and Martin, p. 46.</ref> while her 1944 ''Trio for Violin, Cello and Piano'' has been described as "one of the greatest treasures of Australian music".<ref name=amc>Australian Music Centre.</ref> Reflecting Holland's difficulty in gaining recognition as a serious composer through much of her lifetime, the latter work did not receive its first public performance until 1991, 47 years after it was first written.<ref>[http://cdbaby.com/cd/revolve20 ''Australian Classics''], CD Baby website.</ref>
==Awards== *[[Australian Broadcasting Commission|ABC]]/[[Australasian Performing Right Association|APRA]] awards, 1933, 1944, 1951, 1955 *[[ANZAC]] Festival Awards, 1954, 1955, 1956 *[[General Motors]] Theatre Award, 1963 *[[Henry Lawson]] Award, 1965 *Member of the Order of Australia, 1977<ref>[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=870052&search_type=quick&showInd=true Bellhouse, Dulcie Sybil], It's an Honour, [[Government of Australia]] database of honours. Retrieved 2008-06-05.</ref> *Honorary D.Litt. from Macquarie University, 1993 *AMEB Fellowship in Music, 1994<ref name=resonate/><ref name=amc/>
==Footnotes== {{Reflist}}
==Recurring references== *[http://www.amcoz.com.au/composers/composer.asp?id=3397 Dulcie Holland] - Australian Music Centre website. *[http://www.musicaustralia.org/apps/MA?function=showDetail&currentMapsRecord=ANL:MA~000001001309&itemSeq=1&total=32&&returnFunction=viewTheme&&sessionId= Dulcie Holland] - Music Australia website. *[http://www.resonatemagazine.com.au/article.php?id=135 Dulcie Holland: Building a Foundation] by Rita Crews, ''Resonate'' magazine, 18 April 2008 *Fuller, Sophie and LeFanu, Nicola (1994): ''Reclaiming the Muse'', Routledge, p. 153, {{ISBN|3-7186-5528-4}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xfdWcHo3s28C&pg=PA153&lpg=PA153&dq=+%22dulcie+holland%22&source=web&ots=IUJ_zePq5D&sig=TczZsJPSlOoew1gaDe5bRwTEAtY&hl=en Extract]. *Sitsky, Larry; Martin, Ruth Lee (2005): ''Australian Piano Music of the Twentieth Century'', Greenwood Publishing Group, pp. 43–46, {{ISBN|0-313-32286-4}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3g8PGmIHm3cC&pg=PA43&lpg=PA43&dq=+%22dulcie+holland%22&source=web&ots=v2N-e6djT_&sig=eqMRO4XlD1MEmqSGwGGK-bjFQ9Q&hl=en#PPA43,M1 Extract].

{{Orphan|date=July 2016}}
'''Femme de la rue''' (''Woman of the street'') is a 2012 [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[documentary]] made by [[Sofie Peeters]]. It runs for 25 minutes and deals with the subject of [[sexual harassment]] against women in the city of [[Brussels]]. This documentary was broadcast by [[Canvas (Belgium)|Canvas]] on 26 July 2012. It caused a lot of commotion in both Belgian and Dutch politics about penalizing the harassment of women.<ref>Derek Blyth, ''[http://www.flanderstoday.eu/politics/sexual-harassment-illegal-under-new-belgian-law Sexual harassment illegal under new Belgian law]''. Flanders Today. 14 March 2014.</ref>
==Background==
Sofie Peeters, the author of this documentary, was a student of audiovisual arts at {{ill|Royal Institute for Theatre, Cinema and Sound|nl|RITCS}} (RITCS) at the time of filming. She had moved to [[Brussels]] for these studies, where she was harassed on a daily basis by men on the streets. She decided to film those experiences and turn them into a documentary on sexual street harassment.<ref>{{nl}} Astrid Snoeys, [http://www.demorgen.be/tvmedia/seksisme-in-brussel-aan-de-kaak-gesteld-in-femme-de-la-rue-b91c433c/ Seksisme in Brussel aan de kaak gesteld in 'Femme de la rue']. De Morgen. 26 July 2012. </ref>
This documentary makes use of a [[hidden camera]]. A young woman walks through the streets of Brussels while carrying a hidden camera. The main spots she passes by are the {{ill|Boulevard Maurice Lemonnier|fr}} (Maurice Lemonnierlaan) and the {{ill|Place Anneessens|fr}} (Anneessensplein). During this walk, she is continuously bothered by men who yell at her, offend her, and try to impose themselves unto her. Nearly all the offenders are of Peeters are of North African origin which led to a debate about a cultural border which was not the intent of the author but showed to be important to consider. This documentary also features women of both autochthone and allochthone backgrounds who talk about their experiences while walking the streets of Brussels.
{{Belgium-film-stub}} {{short-documentary-film-stub}}
== References == <references/> * {{nl}} Sofie Peeters, [http://www.demorgen.be/tvmedia/waarover-mijn-documentaire-femme-de-la-rue-echt-gaat-b6005d49/ Waarover mijn documentaire ‘Femme de la Rue’ echt gaat]. De Morgen. 31 July 2012.
==External links== * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2677366/ ''Femme de la rue'' at IMDB]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2014}} The '''G7 Method''' is a printing procedure used for visually accurate color reproduction by putting emphasis on matching grayscale colorimetric measurements between processes. G7 stands for '''g'''rayscale plus '''seven''' colors: the [[subtractive colors]] typically used in printing (Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, and Black) and the [[additive colors]] (Red, Green, and Blue). The method is used in many applications of printing such as [[offset lithography]], [[flexography]], and [[gravure]] since it uses a one-dimensional neutral print density curve (NPDC) to match neutral tonality between two G7 calibrated printing systems. The G7 method is not a completely accurate color management system nor is it officially standardized by the [[International Color Consortium]] (ICC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idealliance.org/specifications/g7/what-g7 |title=What is G7? |publisher=IDEAlliance |date= |accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref>
==History== The G7 method was created by Don Hutcheson, chairman of the IDEAlliance GRACoL (International Digital Enterprise Alliance, General Requirements for Applications in Commercial Offset Lithography) in 2006. It was created to solve the problem of [[computer to plate]] (CtP) printing systems and other devices printing images with different tonal value increases (TVIs), or [[dot gain]]s. Also, professionals in the printing industry follow the [[International Organization for Standardization]]’s (ISO) principles of [[half-tone]] printing, called ISO 12647-2, which does not specify colorimetric values for gray balance and refers to multiple TVI curves. This results in an ambiguous definition of the print’s final ‘appearance’.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://w3.efi.com/~/media/Files/EFI/Fiery/Fiery%20Digital%20Print%20Servers/Demystifying%20Color%20Standards_hr.pdf |title=Demystifying Color Standards |publisher=W3.efi.com |accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref>
The G7 method solved this problem by creating Neutral Print Density Curves (NPDC) that related neutral density to the half-tone dot percentages of a print image rather than a TVI curve relating the input dot percentage to the output gain relative to the input percentage.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Definition==
===Basic Set-up=== To calibrate a printing system with the G7 method, it basically entails comparing the NPDC generated by the device to the ‘ideal’ NPDC given in G7 specifications, calibrating the [[Raster Image Processor]] (RIP) or the driver of the device, and then repeating the NPDC comparison to check for accuracy. More specifically, one dimensional interpolation between the NPDC graph generated by the printer and the GRACoL 7 NPDC “FanGraph” must be done to generate new dot percentage aim values to be given to the device’s RIP or driver.<ref name="hkprinters1">[http://www.aptec.hkprinters.org/IDEAlliance-China/resource_centre/free_resources/08-G7_how-to_v6 ]{{dead link|date=February 2014}}</ref>
===Colorimetry=== The G7 method's emphasis on grayscale calibration is loosely based around the concept of neutralizing the camera image of a scene using a [[gray card]]. This is done to lower the effects of lighting conditions, such as [[color temperature]], on the resulting image. G7 takes this further by defining percentages of cyan, magenta, and yellow ink at which the image should be gray balanced. It also defines values for a* and b* for the [[Lab color space]].<ref name="hkprinters1"/>
Most printing systems use [[half-tone]]s to generate images by using a series of cyan, magenta, yellow, and black dots to recreate colors. This is done by varying the size of the dots so that the human eye can spatially integrate the image's color and make it look like one uniform color.
===Benefits and disadvantages=== Using the G7 method for printing calibration is a manual process and is device independent, meaning it can be used for any printing devices that allows manipulation of the [[raster image processor]] or [[computer to plate]] curve information that dictates how digital signals from an image is printed with ink.
However, since the G7 method relies mostly on gray balance, if the image does not contain much gray information, the calibration can be inaccurate. Also, using any offset printing may be difficult to gray balance because it involves "wet-trapping" which can lead to unpredictable values for dark tones.<ref name="hkprinters1"/>
==Software== '''IDEAlink Curve''' Calibration using the G7 method involves comparing two NPDCs from the G7 Fangraph to calculate new aim values that will be given to the printer's RIP files. This can be a manual process, but the IDEAlink curve software, created by IDEAlliance, does this automatically and with minimal error. Improvements to this program include Curve2 and Curve3. ''IDEAlink Curve 1.1 software is no longer commercially available''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Certified G7 Systems {{!}} Idealliance|url = http://www.idealliance.org/certifications/g7-certifications/g7-system-certification/certified-g7-systems|website = www.idealliance.org|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref> See the list below for systems and software that have received G7 System Certification.
IDEAlliance certifies systems and software that meet or exceed established industry tolerances for excellence and are capable of calibrating a printing device to meet the G7 grayscale definition using four 1-D curves.<ref name=":0" />
G7 Certified systems/software include the following:<ref name=":0" />
'''EFI''' Fiery Color Profile Suite
'''FUJIFILM''' ColorPath™ Sync®<ref>{{Cite web|title = ColorPath Sync {{!}} ColorPath {{!}} Workflow Solutions {{!}} Graphic Arts & Printing {{!}} Fujifilm USA|url = http://www.fujifilmusa.com/products/graphic_arts_printing/workflow-solutions/colorpath/sync/index.html|website = www.fujifilmusa.com|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref>
'''Heidelberg''' Prinect® Color Toolbox <ref>{{Cite web|title = Prinect Color Toolbox with Gray Balance optimizer|url = https://www.idealliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Heidelberg_G7_System_ADS_v3.pdf|website = www.idealliance.org|accessdate = 2018-07-01}}</ref>
'''CHROMiX'''/HutchColor Curve2™<ref>{{Cite web|title = CHROMiX / HutchColor - Curve2: Pressroom Curves for G7 GreyBalance|url = http://www2.chromix.com/curve2/|website = www2.chromix.com|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref>
'''Alwan''' Dynamic Printer Calibration™
'''KODAK''' ColorFlow
'''ColorGATE''' Productionserver / G7 Calibration Module
'''Konica Minolta''' Color Care™ version 2.2.1 with CurveCore™ Module
